issues.description: The ExcellenceLand constructor in the solution has an extra first parameter (String name) that is not an attribute in the UML/problem specification and therefore violates the requirement that each class constructor must take exactly the class attributes in the same order as in the UML. The problem statement (and task 3) expects ExcellenceLand to have attributes (excellencyLevel: double, excellentEnough: boolean, rides: List<Ride>) and the constructor parameters to match those attributes in that order. The solution constructor signature (String name, double excellencyLevel, boolean excellentEnough, List<Ride> rides) is inconsistent and includes an unused/extra parameter, which will confuse students implementing the required constructor and may cause grading/compatibility problems.
issues.suggested_fix: Change the ExcellenceLand constructor to accept exactly the class attributes in the order specified by the UML: (double excellencyLevel, boolean excellentEnough, List<Ride> rides). Remove the extraneous String name parameter (and any unused parameters) and assign the provided parameters to the corresponding fields. Update any callers/tests accordingly.

issues.description: The solution implementation of ExcellenceLand defines a constructor with an extra 'String name' parameter (public ExcellenceLand(String name, double excellencyLevel, boolean excellentEnough, List<Ride> rides)), but the UML/problem specification lists ExcellenceLand attributes as excellencyLevel (double), excellentEnough (boolean) and (per task description) rides (List<Ride>) — there is no 'name' attribute for ExcellenceLand. The exercise requirements also mandate that each class constructor must take parameters exactly corresponding to the UML-defined attributes in the same order. The unexpected 'name' parameter in the solution constructor is unused and causes a mismatch between the problem specification and the solution code, which can confuse students about the expected constructor signature and parameter order.
issues.suggested_fix: Remove the extraneous 'String name' parameter from ExcellenceLand's constructor. Change the constructor signature to match the UML/tasks: public ExcellenceLand(double excellencyLevel, boolean excellentEnough, List<Ride> rides) and assign each parameter to the corresponding private attribute in that order. This restores a clear, one-to-one mapping between the UML-specified attributes and the constructor parameters.
